Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: mercuri2000
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed in Keong Saik Hotel after running through the ratings and comments in Trip Advisor. It's pretty misleading from the pictures shown and I didn't have much of an expectation when I booked this hotel. In gist it's small and they charge 100 SGD for a room, eventhough the advert states that it's 85SGD, perhaps it's additional taxes and what not. The location, decently located within walking distance from the Outram Park MRT, but from the MRT it's difficult to know where is the actual location since there is no landmark to pinpoint it's location. It's located right next to an Indian Temple and it's housed in a pre war shophouses, hence the term 'boutique' hotel. Along the same row there is a ridiculously small 7-11 convenience store. Once in the premises, it's dingy looking and and dark. Electricity bills must be really expensive. It's no frills and the rooms is as small as it can be, similar to hotels in Hong Kong. Hardly had any room to walk. Water is chargeable at 2SGD a pop. The rooms are dark, and the lightings are scarce. There are cracks all over the wall and the most glarring thing is that there is NO WINDOWS, hence no ventilation whatsoever. The bathroom are small and basic, a shower is provided. The mattress is acceptable but not comfy, blankets are old and torn. You get the gist of it. Room doors are thin and there is no latch apart from a safety hook. Breakfast is provided, only 3 in 1 coffee, some juices, bread and eggs. Basic is the word of the day. All in all, it might be a nostalgic experience for some, (not many if I may opine), Perhaps for Westerners this hotel might be appealing since they have not experience it before, but for many asians, the set up of this hotel, it's rooms and the services, are reminiscent of those cheap 'love hotels' where prostitutions are the main business.Would I stay here again? I definitely wont, even if it's the cheapest hotel around. Would I term this a boutique hotel, MOST DEFINATELY NOT.

Reviews.Title: “A simple & economic place in the heart of Chinatown”
Reviews.Author: Smile92
Reviews.Content: We stayed four nights in this hotel which offered low rates in mid-august. This place is old-style but not of bad taste. The first room we were given was small (+/- 15m²), but nice and clean (#101), with a simple decor and dark wooden floor. The bathroom was very small (2.5m²) with a toilet, a sink and a shower with curtains shrinked in. There was plenty of space & closets in the bedroom for our laundry, suitcases etc., as well as a minibar for which we were asked to pay a deposit of 10S$ upon check-in in case we would drink its water bottles! There was no safe in the room which we disliked very much, especially since there was a big warning on the door stating "do not leave any valuable in the room... the hotel management could not be held responsible in case of theft ... blablabla..." which was not reassuring. We had no other choice but to leave some valuables at the Reception's safe, but it was so tiny we had to carry most of them on us permanently. In terms of comfort & quietness, room 101 should be absolutely avoided as it is the closest one to the lobby, the elevator's motor room, the breakfast room, and the noisy Keong Saik road. During the day, we missed some shadow curtains for more intimacy. At night, there was no black curtains at all the cover the upper window, so we suffered from the daylight. The noise was permanent day and night, and worsened by the trendy white cafe across the street with loud music up to 2am (except on sundays). The rates included breakfast so it was cool to have an instant coffee, some toast, cereals and eggs on site. (there are only two coffee table so we guess when the hotel is packed breakfast must become epic!) We asked the hotel to store our bags for 2 nights. The Reception staff agreed but asked us to pay 3S$ per piece, even if we had made a booking for the following night. Of course, for that price, our luggage stayed in the lobby during 48 hours since there is no storage room! It looked like every little extra service has a cost in this hotel, and it was not pleasant. Finally, when we returned, we were given a nice room on the third floor, on the street but away from the elevator. We really enjoyed that one as it was bigger and quieter. If we were given this room from the beginning, we would have stayed in this hotel until the end of our journey. But the room 101 made us sceptical and we moved to a different hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Not 5-star (or even 4) but a good decent place in Chinatown”
Reviews.Author: nzbear
Reviews.Content: Have stayed here quite few times over the last decade. No, it's not top of the line, but it's decently run and I've never had any major cause for complaints. Rooms are basic, and very small: go for the most expensive - it's worth it for the extra space. Breakfast is fairly basic (cereals and toast) but at least it's part of the price. Staff generally helpful. Rooms kept reasonably well by the cleaning staff. Its biggest plus is the location in Chinatown - not too far from Outram Park MRT (an interchange station), and walking distance to almost anywhere in Chinatown. Great food on offer in the area, plus plenty of tourist traps! For the price it's a fairly good deal for Singapore. My only warning: watch out for when the Singapore F1 Night Race is on - prices jump (usually double) for several days. I hadn't been warned that one day of a stay at Keong Saik a couple of years ago overlapped with the F1 days (which were of no interest to me) and had to pay over $200 for my first night.

Reviews.Title: “small, but friendly and with character”
Reviews.Author: wokabaut
Reviews.Content: This hotel doesn't have all the amenities as some, such as a fitness center, but has a lot of character. It's an old hotel, a bit small, but good value and clean. The staff are friendly and a free breakfast and internet are included. Although the internet is only available in the lobby area. The hotel is fairly quiet and located next to a Hindu temple and a short distance from Chinatown shopping. Nor is it far from the subway or the riverfront. We had a good time here. They don't seem to do day rates for those flights coming and leaving around midnight. I'd stay here again. The beds were firm and clean. I couldn't find any outlets though in the bathroom, but don't use them anyway. I'm not sure what their policy is on smoking but could smell it from the road.

Reviews.Title: “DON'T!!!!”
Reviews.Author: Globetr0ttingG0urmet
Reviews.Content: After 1 minute inspection, and appalled at the state of the room, staff refused to give any sort of refund, and said the manager was "not available" without even trying to contact him/her. So if you are tempted by price, DON'T!!! You will be charged regardless if you stay or not. Worse, the hotel keeps your credit card details on file, and when confirming a reservation sends all your confidential info by email. We had to cancel our credit card afterwards because of fraud, as a result. Good location, but there are so many other good hotels on the same street, why stay here when it hasn't been improved for years? Dirty, small. And staff are extremely unhelpful. I am not surprised other TA reviewers call this place a "rip off." Globetrotting Gourmet

Reviews.Title: “Rooms too small.... and old”
Reviews.Author: yl_len246
Reviews.Content: Checked in at this hotel for 2 nights since all hotels at that time were full. We were given two small rooms, the size of a shoebox, to fit in 6 people, Extra bed is simply a mattress on the floor, which devoid it of space to walk around the room..., The furnishings were outdated - maybe it's the theme of their decor? Never tried to have breakfast, as there is no place to eat in their small dining room. The possitive side ... - 3-5 mins walk to outram MRT station - walking distance to chinatown - courteous reception other than that... better stay somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Rip Off”
Reviews.Author: gnc88
Reviews.Content: I cancelled my booking but the hotel's supposedly error-free system did not reflect this and I was charged for 1 night stay. This is totally unacceptable. By all means, avoid this hotel as they simply just put the blame on their customers.

Reviews.Title: “Only the double rooms are worth it”
Reviews.Author: JabberwockyIndia
Reviews.Content: The double rooms are charming, old style furniture. But cramped up. The single room is useless - small and without windows. I would recommend staying in this hotel ONLY if you get a room with windows facing the main road - else avoid it and instead stay at any of the other Singapore star hotels. The service is good and cheerful. Breakfast sparse (juice, microwaved eggs, milk, toast), breakfast space cramped up - 8 is a crowd! I have to admit - the entrance, facade and lobbies all look impressive and have been done up well. Wish they had added some of the walkway space into the rooms instead! This hotel thankfully has a elevator. Internet unfortunately is avbl only in the lobby (charged at 10 sing dollars per day). The lobby has some interesting photos and books to read (I always like that in hotels)

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: theloaders
Reviews.Content: We just stayed two nights at this hotel and found it to be excellent value especially as we were staying over the F1 Grand Prix weekend when every other hotel was full or overcharging for the rooms they had left. Our room at the Keong Saik was very clean, the staff were helpful and the hotel very well located. Close to the MRT, Chinatown and a number of hawker centres were close by. We will definitely consider staying again when we next visit Singapre.

Reviews.Title: “Convenient small hotel”
Reviews.Author: allicanta
Reviews.Content: Convenient location. The hotel is a walking distance to the Outram Park MRT and a walking distance to Chinatown area. Restaurant is only for breakfast -- light breakfast. Room is quite small but if you're only staying in the hotel to sleep or rest for a bit, this is a good place and the price is cheap.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Location”
Reviews.Author: kakek_ganas
Reviews.Content: i book this hotel from internet... well so far the staff were very helpfull, but the hospitality need to be improved, such as: greeting guest every morning etc, but thats not the main point the room size is small, and the bathroom very small. &*%*(&(% the location is very superb, very near with chinatown, if u want to hang out, just go to the bar... near with seven elevem.... just a walk away from OUTRAM PARK city interchange MRT and bus station the only thing that i would not recommend is the breakfast.... very standard... but u can find a lot of much much better breakfast outside, just choose one of ur fave food type: nasi lemak, nasi padang, chinese chuisine, ABF ? all with reasonable price

Reviews.Title: “Good location for China town”
Reviews.Author: kay_kay_uk
Reviews.Content: if you are looking for somewhere right next to, as in 2 streets away from China town then look no further. We looked at all reviews and wanted somewhere in China town, with easy access to MRT to get to and from the airport, somewhere cheap and clean. We got all this from the Keong Saik Hotel. It was easy to jump onto the MRT and get off at either the China town (walk back towards the main road, dont walk towards all the lovely market stalls! take a left and ignore the first road, even though its called the Keong Saik road and take the next left, its just up there on the right) or you could get off at Outram Park, which means no changing trains. Come out of the tube and follow the shelter left along the busy road, until you get to the cross roads with traffic lights, cross over both lanes of traffic, straight up and then the hindu temple is on your right and the Keong Saik hotel is just there. Both routes will take about 2 / 3 mins walking, even with a heavy backpack! The hotel has a lift, a kind of bar / small dinning area where you have breakfast, but be warned it only seats about 6 people, 2 small tables and a small breakfast bar, so if there are lots of people you will have to wait or come back later. The room was clean, if a little small, bathroom was new but again quite small. The aircon only had one setting and wasnt cool enough for us, plus finding the light swtiches (hidden on a panel by the bed) was a mission to find! The breakfast was cereal, coffee, tea, juice, eggs - if someone was around and toast. Basic. We stayed here for 2 nights and it was OK, a bit over priced, but while we were there we couldnt find anything similar near or in chinatown, so when we came back to Singapore we stayed near Raffles and Little India, a bit more expensive and not that much better. Overall i think that coming to Singapore and not spending the world on accommodation is difficult. Its all pricey and not to the highest standard, this is great for China Town location (tons of cheap places to eat and things to do in the evening).

Reviews.Title: “Location good”
Reviews.Author: ray138
Reviews.Content: Stayed in the Keong Saik for 5 nights in January. Booked on the reccomendation of a friend but wasn't very impressed with the room, breakfast or the service.The location is great though, close to the MRT and chinatown markets. When we arrived around 4am for our first night we found our room wasn't even made up with the 3 beds we required and the girl on the front desk wasn't very eager to help us out either. Breakfast was pretty much a cold egg, bread and a choice of one of two cereals every morning. Windows dont open, a/c leaked water and lighting was pretty poor in the room. If it wasnt for the location I would totally disregard this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Clean, spacious room but NOISY”
Reviews.Author: Susietubbbie
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel based on some of the good reviews on this website and had booked myself into a deluxe room (I think it is the one they actually show on their website). The LOCATION is excellent, only a very short walk from Outram Park Interchange MRT and close to the heart of Chinatown. The ROOM was wonderful too: clean and very spacious. Unfortunately, I was on the ground floor, so could not open any windows The VALUE FOR MONEY again was excellent - or so I thought. My big problem with this hotel was NOISE as I got woken up about 6 times in my first (and only) night at this hotel. Guests were still shouting down corridors at migdnight and banging doors while later at night people actually sat on the pavement outside my window chattering at the top of their voices. All this was completed by motorcycles noisily speeding down the street at random intervals. Fortunately, I did not have any problems leaving the hotel the next day and was only charged for the one night I stayed there. I may be fussy about noise but if you value a quiet stay as a top priority like I do, you will not find this hotel a good choice. If you are less concerned about a noisy stay, I can see how this hotel can be a very good find indeed as otherwise it ticks all the right boxes.

Reviews.Title: “Do NOT Stay here”
Reviews.Author: CanadianTraveler081
Reviews.Content: Although this was a cheap find, this was probably the worst hotel that I have ever stayed in. The rooms itself were smelly and dirty. There were (blood) stains on the bed sheets and garbage left in the cabinets. The hotel charges for every thing! Whether you are making a local call (charged per min), a call from room to room or plainly asking the front desk to call you a cab you will get charged. The rooms itself felt like a box. There was no room to even lay down luggage. The hotel staff were also very inconsiderate. We came in from a late flight and the staff didn’t even have the courtesy to tell us that there was a movie crew shooting a movie right in front of our hotel room. We had to wait until they were done. Please do not stay here. The value is not worth what you pay for.

Reviews.Title: “DISAPPOINTING”
Reviews.Author: Merdekaman
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel because of the ratings in Tripadvisor.com...it turns out to be very DISAPPOINTING. The rooms are very small, old, and the worst are the rooms at the Attic, avoid at all cost, you can't even open your luggage because there is no space! And no window, very claustrophobic. The staff were not friendly as well. When I asked to change room, one staff said I can do it at 2pm, so I slept but was rudely awakened at 12pm, so I confronted the person who looks like a supervisor, she called up the staff and the staff said she never said so, and the supervisor defended the staff adamantly. What a horrible customer service!!!! There are many more such budget hotels along Keong Saik Road, I suggests you explore further down the raod...

Reviews.Title: “Avoid this grubby little hotel !!!”
Reviews.Author: AUSSIETRAVELADVISER
Reviews.Content: I selected this hotel on the basis of a Trip Adviser review. A ghastly mistake. The hotel stank of durian, the room was a dark cell, there were pile drivers operating next door. When I said that the room was not suitable the desk clerk said "bad luck we will charge you anyway" - and they did when I moved out. AVOID AT ALL COST - there are many reasonable hotels in this area of China Town - ALL better than the Keong Saik !!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “superb value for money”
Reviews.Author: 2o2y
Reviews.Content: I have just returned home from a 2 week stay in Singapore. I stayed at the Keong Saik Hotel for 14 nights. Because of the length of my stay, I was given a discount and paid only S$90 per night for a double room, which given the cost of accomodation in Singapore, is a fantastic rate. The room itself had reasonable space to move around, and had in it a queen size bed, tv, airconditioning (very important in Singapore weather), a wardrobe, mini bar, tea/coffee making facilities, a small desk, bathroom with shower and toilet. Although not modern, the room was clean, comfortable and fulfilled my needs as a budget traveller. The location of the hotel is absolutely superb. It is in the heart of Chinatown, with eateries nearby, and within a short walk of the Chinatown and Outram Park MRT stations. It is also within walking distance of entertainment areas such as Clarke Quay. For me, this is a great location, as i saved a lot of money by not having to take a taxi back to the hotel after a late night. The only criticism I have of this hotel is that there is not much sound insulation from the road below, so expect to hear a rubbish truck or loud cars passing the hotel throughout the night. Unless I win the lottery and can then afford to stay at Raffles', I'll definitely be staying at this hotel again on my next visit to Singapore.

Reviews.Title: “best choice boutique in chinatown”
Reviews.Author: mamen7
Reviews.Content: I stayed there for one night, and so regreted that I hadn't had any resevervation before so I couldn't stay with them longer. Don't be misjudged by its outside, yes, it's rather old but its facilities are quite well. just under 100 SGD, you can spend a comfortable night, then have breakfast in the next morning, and within few steps, you can get to the Outram park MRT station which connects both East-West line and North-East line. It's also near a market at Chinatown Heritage center - where you can find souvenirs of reasonable price! Great location!

Reviews.Title: “Great budget hotel in Chinatown!”
Reviews.Author: francisjude
Reviews.Content: Since we took this holiday with our four -year-old boy, I was quite careful in choosing the hotel where we could stay in Singapore. Tripadvisor reviews basically helped me decide in booking at this hotel. My husband and I spent a total of five nights with our toddler. Although we arrived from the airport in the wee hours of the morning, the male receptionist welcomed us with a smile. We were placed in Superior Room with big windows at S$90/night. The room, though small, was very clean and cozy, with classic furnishings. My little boy immediately felt comfortable and we always had a restful sleep each night after a day of going around the city. The bathroom smells nice and always dry when we go back to our room at night. Save for the TV with very few channels, everything in the room is in great order - clean towels and linens, shiny wooden floors, bathroom with no mildew, a tea/coffee-making facility and minibar. We never had a need to call housekeeping for anything. Breakfast is simple, but enough to start your day. The staff are quite friendly, though a little more smile on their faces would be appreciated. They took good care of keeping our belongings when we left for a few days for KL. Everything is intact when we got back and stayed for one more night. They even granted our request for a late check-out on our last day. Location is great - it's only a few steps away from the Outram MRT station, a leisurely walk to the Chinatown market and MRT station, and you are surrounded by nice local restaurants. Convenience stores and internet facilities are just a few doorsteps from the hotel. Overall, you will get good value for your money. Don't know how it compares with backpacker hostels around the area, but we are definitely happy we chose Keong Saik hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent budget hotel!”
Reviews.Author: ndutbobo
Reviews.Content: If you really look for a budget but excellent stay hotel in Singapore, this will be a best choice! It is for sure provide simple services but with everything you need. Located in the centre of China Town, you could easily reach the Night Market of Smith Street only in minutes for food festive of Singapore. Heading for shopping in Orchard Rd? Outram Park MRT is only in your backyard with only one stop to get to Vivo City in Harbour Front. The breakfast is simple, it will get you enough to start-off the morning until lunch! On top of all, the room is clean and everything is working well including the shower attached bath-room. It will provide you with a nice and comfy evening for the rest after long-walk around Singapore. I think I will stay again here for the next visit if I am not trying to get luxurious life there! Keep up the good service!

Reviews.Title: “A great budget hotel!”
Reviews.Author: marxusboy
Reviews.Content: Stayed here 4 nights in January 2007. My first impression was good: kind and smiling reception staff, a spacious air-conditioned lobby, a general impression of cleanliness and good organization. They offer three types of rooms: standard, superior and deluxe. The rates they currently have on their website [--] are not accurate; when I visited, they were charging SGD 70, 80 and 90 respectively for a single room, SGD 10 extra for a twin/double. I stayed in a standard room since this is basically all they had left when I arrived. My room, number 104, was on the main floor, darkish (no window) and not really inviting. The room felt musty, but upon inserting my room key in the provided slot, the air con turned on and I started to feel more comfortable within about 10 minutes. What I liked about the room: it was clean, with nice wooden floors and a large firm bed with clean sheets, a decent-sized closet with a few hangers, a small working table with wooden stool, a phone, a neat bathroom (albeit small) with good water pressure and a shower curtain to separate the shower area from the rest of the bathroom (you wonder why most budget hotels here in Singapore don’t even bother to install shower curtains in their bathrooms!). My room also featured one of these remote control units for the lights that you usually find in more expensive hotels, although it malfunctioned a couple of times during my stay, turning on the entry light around 6-7 AM on a couple of occasions. The remote control unit also controlled the air conditioning and the TV. Regarding the TV, I don’t understand why they bothered installing a 20-inch colour TV in the room while giving you access to only one channel with a crisp image! The only thing I disliked about the room was the lack of a window, which makes the room downright depressing. Don’t plan on spending any serious time in there when you’re not sleeping! Anyway, if you book long enough in advance, you should be able to get one of their deluxe or superior rooms, all with windows. If you want a room that faces Keong Saik Street, be advised that these rooms only come with two twin beds, which might not be to your liking. The clincher for me, I must say, was their wireless Internet access. The good news is that unlimited access only costs SGD 8 per day (this is a steal if you compare that to the $30 charged by Hotel 81 in Chinatown!). The bad news, however, is that you can only access it from the lobby and the breakfast area, which makes the price far less of a deal. Hopefully, this will have been remedied by the time you stay here. I visited a lot of budget hotels while in this part of Singapore and can safely say that this place is one of the better deals: for the price, you get a clean room, regular smiles from the front desk staff and even a basic breakfast thrown in! If you want a budget hotel in this city, you better do your homework carefully because there are a lot of dives in Singapore, especially in Chinatown and in the East. This place is definitely not one of them.

Reviews.Title: “GREAT - and then some”
Reviews.Author: esorlegin
Reviews.Content: We booked into Keong Saik for the first 6 days of our 3 weeks in S E Asia. The staff are so helpful and friendly, the rooms are clean and tidy and the beds are very comfortable. DO NOT expect the Ritz and you will have a great time. Rooms at the back second floor (207,208) can be a bit noisy due to the airconditioning equpiment. Nothing that will stop you sleeping. Rooms at the front are (mostly) quiet and have some street views. To give you a point of reference - we also stayed at Traders in KL - we do enjoy our comforts. Next time we visit Singapore, we will be staying here. MRT is only 2 minutes away and there are many local restaurants to enjoy.

Reviews.Title: “Smart and efficient”
Reviews.Author: JuergenHeinrich
Reviews.Content: I had the basic single room with no window for 65 SGD internet rate. I mean a Singapore hotel room at that low rate will not offer you facilities of an let's say 90 SGD room. There are no spacious bath rooms, no 100 channel TV, there is no fancy breakfast buffet, there is nobody who carries your luggage. I think the point is: tends that cheap hotel to "noisy, dirty, unfriendly and bad located" or tends it to "quiet, clean, friendly and well located". In my opinion Keong Saik Hotel tends to mostly quiet, very clean and smart, quite friendly and well located if you enjoy squeezed and lively areas like Chinatown. I found the room very small but smart arranged and everything in a good shape, absolutely clean, everything works,.the materials used are nice, wooden floor in good condition, no cheap bath room tiles, huge wardrobe with many hangers, the air condition is individually controlable. The bath room is bright and clean and very small, indeed, app. 1,5 m x 2 m for toilet, washbasin and shower all together, but you got large clean towels, soap and shampoo, and the shower curtain is long enough not to turn your room into a swimming pool, everything is smart installed. The bed is around 180 cm, rather short. The mattress comfortable hard. The linen clean. The breakfast follows, let's say, Chinese pragmatism. Everything is prepacked, instant coffee sachets, jam and butter packages, cornflakes in 200g packs, even the toast is still wrapped. One chafing dish with fried eggs is the only cooked thing you meet at breakfast. A thermos to make your tea or coffee and carafes with milk and orange syrup you will also meet. Make the best of it to start your day and read the daily newspaper Strait Times they provide. Choose amongst two small tables and a kitchen bar with four high chairs to have a seat. Yes, it is squeezed and some may say it's a joke but it gives you the essential start to the day (as someone already said in the review of Feb 25, 2006). The staff is friendly, there was no problem to fix, so I cannot rate their willingness and ability to help. The location is double-edged, I think. Keong Saik Road is part of an amusement district in Chinatown, so certainly a nice place to get cheap food in simple shops and late night entertainment in clubs and bars. Nobody disturbs or approaches the hotel guests, and as everywhere in Singapore it's secure. The MRT is few hundred meters close to bring you to finer places if you want. Therefore I would not stay with my family or for honeymoon in that area and all its squeezed hotels. I come frequently to Singapore and know hotel rooms of 90 SGD and 135 SGD category, overall it was good value for money. If you can spend 90 SGD I would recommend the area of Bencoolen Street and its hotels.

HotelInfo.Name: Keong Saik Hotel
HotelInfo.Address: 69 Keong Saik Road, Singapore 089165, Singapore
